questions.text: Rhinitis sicca is most commonly seen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Rhinitis sicca, also known as atrophic rhinitis or dry rhinitis, is most commonly seen in the anterior nares (Option A). This condition is characterized by dryness, crusting, and sometimes bleeding of the nasal mucosa. The anterior nares are particularly susceptible because they are directly exposed to external environmental factors such as dust, dry air, pollution, and irritants. Additionally, the anterior nasal mucosa contains a higher density of sebaceous and sweat glands, making it more prone to drying out. The lack of proper humidification and moisture balance in this region leads to mucosal atrophy and crust formation, making it the most common site for rhinitis sicca. Incorrect Options: Option B (Posterior nares): The posterior nares are located deeper in the nasal cavity and are less exposed to external environmental factors. This region maintains better humidity and is less likely to suffer from dryness and crusting associated with rhinitis sicca. Option C (Supreme meatus): The supreme meatus is a less common anatomical variant in the superior part of the nasal cavity. It is not a primary site for rhinitis sicca because it is relatively protected from direct environmental exposure and has less airflow turbulence. Option D (Superior meatus): The superior meatus, located beneath the superior nasal concha, is not a primary site for rhinitis sicca. This area has a relatively lower airflow and is less prone to desiccation compared to the anterior nares, making it an uncommon site for this condition.

questions.text: All of the following are causes of Rhinolalia Clauses except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Rhinolalia Clausa (Closed Nasality) is a speech disorder characterized by reduced nasal resonance due to obstruction of the nasal passages or nasopharynx. It results in a muffled or hyponasal speech quality, often described as a "blocked nose" voice. The correct answer is Option D (Velopharyngeal Insufficiency) because this condition leads to Rhinolalia Aperta (Open Nasality), not Rhinolalia Clausa. Option D (Velopharyngeal Insufficiency - VPI): This condition occurs when the soft palate fails to close properly against the posterior pharyngeal wall, allowing excessive air to escape through the nose during speech. This results in hypernasality (Rhinolalia Aperta) rather than closed nasality (Rhinolalia Clausa), making this the correct exception. Incorrect Options: Option A (Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma): A tumor in the nasopharynx can obstruct the nasal airway, leading to hyponasal speech (Rhinolalia Clausa). It can also cause Eustachian tube dysfunction and nasal congestion, further contributing to nasal obstruction. Option B (Hypertrophied Adenoids): Enlarged adenoids block the nasopharynx, preventing normal nasal resonance and causing Rhinolalia Clausa. This is common in children and is often associated with mouth breathing and snoring. Option C (Allergic Rhinitis): Chronic nasal congestion due to allergic rhinitis can reduce nasal airflow, leading to temporary Rhinolalia Clausa. Swelling of the nasal mucosa and excessive mucus production contribute to the obstruction.

questions.text: Hypernasality with stridor is seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hypernasality with stridor is most commonly seen in bilateral abductor palsy (Option B). This condition occurs due to paralysis of both posterior cricoarytenoid (PCA) muscles, which are responsible for abducting (opening) the vocal cords. When both vocal cords remain in a paramedian or median position, the airway becomes significantly narrowed, leading to inspiratory stridor due to turbulent airflow. Additionally, the inability to properly open the glottis can lead to compensatory hypernasality as the patient struggles to generate adequate airflow for speech. This condition often requires medical intervention, such as tracheostomy, to secure the airway. Incorrect Options: Option A (Unilateral abductor palsy): In unilateral abductor palsy, only one vocal cord is affected, while the other remains functional. This may cause mild hoarseness or breathy voice, but it usually does not result in significant airway obstruction or hypernasality with stridor. Stridor is more characteristic of bilateral involvement due to severe airway compromise. Option C (Laryngomalacia): Laryngomalacia is a congenital condition characterized by floppy laryngeal structures, particularly the epiglottis and arytenoid cartilages, which collapse during inspiration, leading to stridor. However, it does not cause hypernasality, as it primarily affects the supraglottic region rather than the vocal cords. Option D (None): This option is incorrect because bilateral abductor palsy is a well-known cause of both hypernasality and stridor due to significant airway obstruction and compensatory speech alterations.

choices.text: Adenoids which are blocking the airways

questions.text: The commonest cause of unilateral mucopurulent rhinorrhoea in a child is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The most common cause of unilateral mucopurulent rhinorrhea in a child is a foreign body in the nose (Option A). Young children frequently insert small objects such as beads, peas, or paper into their nostrils, often without caregivers noticing. These foreign bodies cause localized inflammation, bacterial infection, and foul-smelling mucopurulent nasal discharge, which is typically unilateral. If left untreated, it can lead to complications such as septal perforation or sinusitis. Incorrect Options: Option B (Adenoids which are blocking the airways): While hypertrophied adenoids can lead to chronic nasal obstruction, mouth breathing, and recurrent infections, they typically cause bilateral nasal discharge rather than unilateral mucopurulent rhinorrhea. Option C (Deviated nasal septum - DNS): A deviated septum may cause nasal obstruction, congestion, and sinus infections but does not usually result in unilateral mucopurulent discharge. Instead, it leads to chronic nasal symptoms affecting both sides, though one side may be more obstructed. Option D (Inadequately treated acute frontal sinusitis): Frontal sinusitis is rare in young children because the frontal sinuses are underdeveloped until around 7–8 years of age. Additionally, sinusitis typically causes bilateral nasal symptoms unless it is complicated by a secondary bacterial infection in one sinus.

choices.text: Nasal cavity is filled with greenish crusts

questions.text: All are true about ozaena except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ozaena, also known as atrophic rhinitis, is a chronic nasal condition characterized by progressive atrophy of the nasal mucosa and underlying bone, leading to the formation of foul-smelling, greenish crusts and nasal obstruction. The correct answer is Option B (It is usually unilateral) because ozaena is typically bilateral, not unilateral. Option B (It is usually unilateral) – Incorrect Statement: Ozaena is almost always bilateral, affecting both nasal cavities. Unilateral atrophic rhinitis is extremely rare and usually occurs due to secondary causes such as trauma or surgery. Other Options: Option A (Common in females) – True: Ozaena is more common in females, especially in young adults and postmenopausal women. The exact reason for this gender predominance is unknown, but hormonal influences may play a role. Option C (Nasal cavity is filled with greenish crusts) – True: A hallmark feature of ozaena is the presence of thick, greenish, foul-smelling crusts within the nasal cavity. These crusts, when removed, expose an atrophic mucosa that is often insensitive due to nerve damage. Option D (Atrophic rhinitis) – True: Ozaena is a form of primary atrophic rhinitis, characterized by progressive atrophy of nasal mucosa and turbinates, leading to an abnormally wide nasal cavity and loss of normal nasal secretions.

questions.text: Unilateral pain, purulent rhinorrhea and epistaxis are diagnositic of ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) (Rhinolith) because unilateral pain, purulent rhinorrhea, and epistaxis are classic signs of a nasal stone (rhinolith). A rhinolith is a calcified mass that forms around a small foreign body or dried nasal secretions inside the nasal cavity. Over time, minerals from nasal secretions deposit around the foreign object, leading to gradual enlargement, irritation, and secondary infection. This can cause: Unilateral nasal pain due to inflammation Foul-smelling purulent rhinorrhea from chronic infection Intermittent epistaxis (nosebleeds) due to irritation of the nasal mucosa Incorrect Options: Option A (Rhinophyma): Rhinophyma is a severe form of rosacea that leads to thickened, bulbous nasal skin due to sebaceous gland hypertrophy. It does not cause unilateral pain, purulent rhinorrhea, or epistaxis. Option C (Keratotic Papilloma): Keratotic papillomas are benign nasal tumors associated with hyperkeratosis and squamous proliferation. They typically present as nasal obstruction rather than purulent discharge or bleeding. Option D (Inverted Papilloma): Inverted papillomas are benign but locally aggressive nasal tumors arising from the lateral nasal wall. They usually present with nasal obstruction and occasional epistaxis, but unilateral purulent rhinorrhea is not a key diagnostic feature unless secondary infection occurs.

questions.text: A wide roomy nasal cavity with thick crust formation and disfigured hard external nose is seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) (Rhinoscleroma). Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease of the nasal cavity caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It progresses through three stages—catarrhal, granulomatous, and sclerotic (fibrotic)—ultimately leading to a wide, roomy nasal cavity due to destruction of nasal structures, thick crust formation, and external nasal deformity. Wide roomy nasal cavity: This results from mucosal atrophy and destruction of nasal turbinates as the disease progresses. Thick crust formation: Due to chronic inflammation, necrosis, and fibrosis, thick crusts develop inside the nasal cavity. Disfigured hard external nose: The sclerotic phase leads to fibrosis and scarring, causing a woody, hard consistency of the external nose, leading to deformity. Rhinoscleroma primarily affects people in tropical and subtropical regions and is often associated with poor hygiene and chronic nasal infections. Diagnosis is confirmed through histopathology showing Mikulicz cells and Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis on culture. Incorrect Options: Option A (Atrophic Rhinitis): Atrophic rhinitis also leads to a wide roomy nasal cavity and thick greenish crusts, but it does not cause a hard, disfigured external nose. Instead, it results in foul-smelling nasal discharge (ozaena), mucosal atrophy, and loss of nasal turbinates without significant external nasal deformity. Option B (Rhinosporidiosis): Rhinosporidiosis, caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, presents with polypoidal, friable, vascular masses inside the nasal cavity. It does not cause a wide nasal cavity or external nasal deformity but instead leads to recurrent epistaxis and nasal obstruction. Option D (Rhinitis Sicca): Rhinitis sicca is a mild chronic nasal dryness seen in people exposed to dry climates, air conditioning, or irritants. It causes dryness and crusting but does not result in nasal cavity widening, crust accumulation, or external nasal disfigurement.

questions.text: McGovern's technique is used for management of :-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) (Choanal Atresia). McGovern's technique is a surgical method used for the management of choanal atresia, a congenital condition in which the posterior nasal passage (choana) is blocked by either bone or membranous tissue, preventing proper airflow from the nose to the pharynx. McGovern’s technique involves: The placement of an endotracheal tube or stent in the choana after surgical correction of the atresia. This stent helps prevent restenosis (reclosure of the airway) by maintaining the patency of the newly created opening. It is commonly used postoperatively, especially in cases of bilateral choanal atresia, which can cause life-threatening respiratory distress in newborns. Incorrect Options: Option A (Foreign body nose): The removal of a nasal foreign body is done using techniques such as positive pressure methods, forceps extraction, or suction catheters, but McGovern’s technique is not used in this scenario. Option B (Atrophic rhinitis): Atrophic rhinitis is managed with saline douches, topical antibiotics, nasal irrigation, and sometimes Young’s operation, but McGovern’s technique is not applicable. Option C (Hypertrophic rhinitis): Hypertrophic rhinitis is treated with nasal decongestants, corticosteroids, and in severe cases, turbinate reduction surgery (e.g., submucosal diathermy or turbinectomy). McGovern’s technique has no role in its management.

questions.text: Treatment of choice of vasomotor rhinitis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) (Vidian neurectomy). Vidian neurectomy is the treatment of choice for vasomotor rhinitis, a condition characterized by chronic nasal congestion, rhinorrhea (runny nose), and postnasal drip due to an imbalance in autonomic nervous system regulation of nasal blood flow. Unlike allergic rhinitis, vasomotor rhinitis is not triggered by allergens but by non-specific stimuli such as temperature changes, strong odors, stress, or humidity. Vidian Neurectomy (Surgical Treatment of Choice): The Vidian nerve carries parasympathetic fibers that stimulate excessive nasal gland secretion and congestion. Surgical transection (Vidian neurectomy) disrupts this pathway, reducing excess nasal secretions and congestion permanently. It is reserved for severe, medication-resistant cases of vasomotor rhinitis. Incorrect Options: Option B (Steroids): Intranasal corticosteroids (e.g., fluticasone, budesonide) can temporarily reduce nasal inflammation and congestion but are not a definitive cure for vasomotor rhinitis. Option C (Antibiotics): Vasomotor rhinitis is a non-infectious condition and does not involve bacterial pathogens, so antibiotics have no role in its treatment. Option D (Anti-allergic medications): Unlike allergic rhinitis, vasomotor rhinitis is not caused by allergens or histamine release, so antihistamines (anti-allergic drugs) provide little to no relief.

Correct Answer (C) (Sphenopalatine Ganglion). Sluder’s neuralgia, also known as sphenopalatine neuralgia, is a rare type of facial pain that originates from the sphenopalatine ganglion (SPG). This ganglion is located in the pterygopalatine fossa and is associated with the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve (V2). Characteristics of Sluder’s Neuralgia: Severe, unilateral deep-seated pain in the nose, behind the eye, and sometimes radiating to the temple and upper jaw. Associated symptoms like lacrimation, rhinorrhea, nasal congestion, and conjunctival injection due to autonomic involvement. Triggered by nasal irritation, infections, or vascular disturbances. Treatment includes nerve blocks, medications (e.g., carbamazepine, gabapentin), and in severe cases, SPG ablation or resection. Incorrect Options: Option A (Arnold nerve - Auricular Branch of Vagus Nerve): Arnold’s nerve supplies part of the external ear and external auditory canal. It is involved in Arnold’s neuralgia, which causes ear pain and cough reflex when the ear canal is stimulated. It does not play a role in Sluder’s neuralgia, making this option incorrect. Option B (Posterior Ethmoid Nerve): The posterior ethmoid nerve is a branch of the nasociliary nerve (from V1, ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve). It provides sensory innervation to the posterior ethmoid and sphenoid sinuses. It is not associated with Sluder’s neuralgia, so this option is incorrect. Option D (Trigeminal Nerve): The trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) is the main sensory nerve of the face. While the maxillary division (V2) contributes fibers to the sphenopalatine ganglion, the direct source of pain in Sluder’s neuralgia is the sphenopalatine ganglion itself, not the trigeminal nerve as a whole.

questions.text: 20 yrs old male presented with thick sticky nasal discharge and nasal obstruction since last 6 months. On examination hypertrophy of nasal mucosa seen, Which turbinate seem to be involved ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) (Inferior Turbinate). In a 20-year-old male with thick sticky nasal discharge and nasal obstruction for 6 months, the most likely cause is chronic hypertrophic rhinitis, allergic rhinitis, or vasomotor rhinitis. The inferior turbinate is the most commonly involved structure in these conditions due to its large size and role in nasal airflow regulation. The inferior turbinate is the largest of the three nasal turbinates and is highly vascular. Chronic irritation (allergic, infectious, or environmental) leads to hypertrophy of the inferior turbinate, causing nasal obstruction. The thick, sticky discharge suggests chronic inflammation affecting the mucous glands of the inferior turbinate, which plays a primary role in humidifying and filtering air. Treatment options include intranasal corticosteroids, decongestants, and, in severe cases, turbinate reduction surgery (radiofrequency ablation, turbinectomy). Incorrect Options: Option A (Superior Turbinate): The superior turbinate is small and primarily involved in the olfactory function. It is not commonly involved in nasal obstruction or thick discharge. Option B (Middle Turbinate): The middle turbinate is associated with the osteomeatal complex, which drains the frontal, maxillary, and anterior ethmoidal sinuses. While middle turbinate hypertrophy can occur in conditions like concha bullosa or chronic sinusitis, it is not the most commonly involved turbinate in chronic nasal obstruction and discharge. Option D (None): Since hypertrophy of the nasal mucosa is seen, at least one turbinate must be involved, ruling out this option.

questions.text: 20 yrs old female presented with nasal obstruction and epistaxis. On examination nasal cavity was full of foul smelling crusts. Diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) (Atrophic Rhinitis). A 20-year-old female presenting with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and foul-smelling crusts is highly suggestive of atrophic rhinitis. Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic condition characterized by progressive atrophy of the nasal mucosa, turbinates, and even the underlying bone, leading to a wide, roomy nasal cavity filled with thick, greenish, foul-smelling crusts (ozena). The epistaxis (nosebleeds) occurs due to fragile, atrophic mucosa that cracks easily. Patients experience paradoxical nasal obstruction: despite a wide nasal cavity, the thick crusts block airflow, making them feel congested. Other symptoms include anosmia (loss of smell), nasal dryness, and a characteristic fetid odor. Common in young females, especially in tropical and developing regions. Treatment includes nasal irrigation, saline douches, topical antibiotics, and, in severe cases, Young’s operation (surgically narrowing the nasal cavity to reduce crusting). Incorrect Options: Option A (Hypertrophic Rhinitis): Causes thickening (hypertrophy) of nasal mucosa, leading to persistent nasal congestion. Does not present with foul-smelling crusts or epistaxis. Option C (Rhinitis Sicca): A milder form of nasal dryness seen in dry climates or excessive air conditioning exposure. Does not cause severe atrophy, crust formation, or a fetid odor. Option D (Rhinitis Caseosa): A rare condition where caseous (cheesy) material accumulates in the nasal cavity due to chronic inflammation. Does not present with significant mucosal atrophy or crusting, making it less likely.

questions.text: Bloated plasma cells with bifringent inclusions are feature of ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) (Rhinoscleroma). Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease of the upper respiratory tract caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It progresses in three stages: catarrhal, granulomatous, and sclerotic (fibrotic). One of its characteristic histopathological findings is the presence of bloated plasma cells with birefringent inclusions, known as Mikulicz cells. Mikulicz cells are large, foamy histiocytes (bloated plasma cells) that contain intracellular Gram-negative Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis bacteria. These cells have PAS-positive, birefringent cytoplasmic inclusions, which help in the definitive diagnosis of rhinoscleroma. Rhinoscleroma primarily affects the nasal cavity, leading to nasal obstruction, crusting, and external nasal deformity (woody, hard nose) in advanced stages. The disease is common in tropical and developing regions and is associated with poor hygiene. Treatment includes prolonged antibiotic therapy (e.g., tetracyclines, ciprofloxacin, or rifampicin) and, in severe cases, surgical intervention. Incorrect Options: Option A (Hypertrophic Rhinitis): Involves chronic thickening (hypertrophy) of nasal mucosa, leading to persistent nasal congestion and discharge. Does not show bloated plasma cells or birefringent inclusions. Option B (Rhinosporidiosis): A fungal-like infection caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, presenting with friable, polypoidal, vascular nasal masses. Histopathology shows sporangia filled with endospores, not bloated plasma cells. Option D (Rhinitis Caseosa): A rare condition where caseous (cheesy) material accumulates in the nasal cavity due to chronic inflammation. No Mikulicz cells or birefringent inclusions are seen.

questions.text: The earliest sign of congenital syphilis usually rhinitis, or "snuffles" appear after?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) (2-6 weeks). Congenital syphilis is a transplacental infection caused by Treponema pallidum. The earliest clinical sign in an infected newborn is syphilitic rhinitis, also known as "snuffles", which typically appears between 2 to 6 weeks of life. Severe inflammation of the nasal mucosa caused by T. pallidum leads to profuse, mucoid, or blood-tinged nasal discharge, which later becomes purulent. The nasal discharge is highly infectious due to the presence of Treponema pallidum. Infants with syphilitic rhinitis often have nasal obstruction, making breathing difficult, especially while feeding. If untreated, this progresses to destruction of nasal cartilage, saddle nose deformity, and secondary bacterial infections. Incorrect Options: Option A (2-6 days): Symptoms of congenital syphilis do not appear in the first few days after birth. Early manifestations typically begin after 2 weeks, making this option incorrect. Option C (7 days): Syphilitic rhinitis does not develop within just one week. The incubation period and immune response take longer (typically 2-6 weeks). Option D (7 weeks): While some cases may present after 6 weeks, most infants develop symptoms earlier, around 2-6 weeks, making this option less precise.

questions.text: Most common site of tuberculosis in nasal cavity is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) (Anterior end of inferior turbinate). Tuberculosis of the nasal cavity is rare but can occur due to direct inoculation or hematogenous spread from pulmonary tuberculosis. The most common site of involvement is the anterior end of the inferior turbinate due to its exposure to inhaled air and irritants. The inferior turbinate is the largest and most vascular turbinate, making it prone to infection. The anterior end is highly exposed to inhaled pathogens and is frequently traumatized, allowing Mycobacterium tuberculosis to enter and establish infection. Clinical features include ulceration, granulations, nasal obstruction, crusting, epistaxis (nosebleeds), and caseous necrosis. Histopathology shows epithelioid cell granulomas, Langhans giant cells, and caseous necrosis. Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy, Ziehl-Neelsen staining, and PCR for M. tuberculosis. Incorrect Options: Option B (Posterior End of Inferior Turbinate): Less commonly involved because infection usually affects areas with greater exposure to inhaled air and trauma. The posterior end is less prone to direct infection. Option C (Anterior End of Middle Turbinate): The middle turbinate is less exposed to direct inhalation of infected droplets, making it a less frequent site of tuberculosis. Option D (Posterior End of Middle Turbinate): The posterior end is located deeper in the nasal cavity, where tuberculosis is uncommon. It is usually affected in secondary spread from the nasopharynx or sinuses, not as the primary site.

questions.text: Most common head and neck symptom of wegener’s granulomatosis ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) (Recurrent and chronic sinusitis). Wegener’s granulomatosis, now known as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA), is a systemic necrotizing vasculitis affecting small to medium-sized blood vessels, primarily involving the respiratory tract (upper and lower) and kidneys. Sinus involvement is the most common head and neck manifestation of GPA. Inflammation of nasal and paranasal sinus mucosa leads to persistent or recurrent sinusitis, nasal obstruction, and purulent discharge. Granulomatous inflammation and vasculitis result in mucosal ulcerations, nasal septal perforation, and saddle nose deformity in advanced cases. Other associated nasal symptoms: epistaxis (nosebleeds), crusting, and facial pain. Diagnosis is confirmed by c-ANCA (PR3-ANCA), biopsy showing necrotizing granulomas, and systemic involvement (lungs, kidneys, skin, eyes). Incorrect Options: Option A (Ulcerative Lesions): Ulcerative lesions in the nasal cavity or oral mucosa can occur but are not the most common symptom. They are seen later in the disease when tissue destruction becomes more severe. Option B (Subglottic Stenosis): Tracheal and laryngeal involvement can occur, leading to subglottic stenosis and stridor, but it is less common than chronic sinusitis. Option C (Serous Chronic Otitis Media): Otitis media with effusion can occur due to Eustachian tube dysfunction from nasal and sinus inflammation. However, it is not the most common symptom in GPA.

questions.text: Untrue statement regarding Non-healing midline granuloma (Polymorphic Reticulosis) is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) (Renal involvement), as it is an untrue statement. Non-healing midline granuloma, also known as Polymorphic Reticulosis or Extranodal NK/T-cell Lymphoma, Nasal Type, is a rare, aggressive disorder affecting the upper respiratory tract, particularly the nasal cavity, paranasal sinuses, and midline structures. It is part of the lymphoma spectrum and is linked to Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) infection. Unlike Wegener’s Granulomatosis (Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis - GPA), which involves the kidneys, Polymorphic Reticulosis does not cause renal involvement. The disease is localized to the upper respiratory tract and midline structures with no systemic renal complications. Kidney involvement in a patient with midline granuloma would suggest another vasculitic or systemic disorder, such as GPA. Incorrect Options: Option A (No Pulmonary Involvement) – True: The disease is localized to the upper respiratory tract and does not spread to the lungs in most cases. Unlike Wegener’s Granulomatosis (GPA), which commonly affects the lungs and kidneys, Polymorphic Reticulosis is confined to midline structures. Option C (Treatment Includes Radiotherapy) – True: Radiotherapy is the primary treatment for localized disease. Chemotherapy (CHOP regimen) may be added for advanced or aggressive cases. Option D (Treatment Includes Surgery) – True: Surgery is not the primary treatment but may be considered in cases of localized necrotic tissue removal or reconstructive procedures after disease control. Complete surgical excision is usually not curative, as the disease is primarily treated with radiotherapy and chemotherapy.

questions.text: Which of the following sinus is not visible on Water’s View
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) (Posterior Ethmoid Sinus). Water’s View (Occipitomental View) is an X-ray projection used primarily to evaluate the paranasal sinuses. It is taken with the patient’s mouth open and the X-ray beam angled to best visualize the maxillary, frontal, and anterior ethmoid sinuses. However, the posterior ethmoid sinuses are not well visualized in this view. Water’s View primarily highlights the maxillary sinuses because the X-ray beam is angled in a way that projects the petrous ridges below the maxillary sinuses. The anterior ethmoid and frontal sinuses are partially visible, but the posterior ethmoid sinuses lie too far back and are obscured by other structures. The best view for posterior ethmoid and sphenoid sinuses is the Lateral View or Caldwell View (Occipitofrontal View). Incorrect Options: Option A (Maxillary Sinus) – Visible: The maxillary sinus is the most prominently seen in Water’s View. Option B (Sphenoid Sinus) – Partially Visible in Open Mouth View: If the patient opens their mouth, the sphenoid sinus can be seen through the open foramen magnum, but it is not the primary sinus assessed in this view. The best view for sphenoid sinuses is the Lateral View or Submentovertex (SMV) View. Option C (Frontal Sinus) – Partially Visible: The frontal sinuses can be seen, but they are not as well visualized as the maxillary sinuses. The Caldwell View (Occipitofrontal View) is the best view for frontal sinuses.

questions.text: In Caldwell-Luc procedure the incision is made in the :-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) (Gingivobuccal sulcus). The Caldwell-Luc procedure is a surgical technique used to access the maxillary sinus for drainage, removal of diseased tissue, or excision of tumors. It involves creating an opening in the anterior wall of the maxillary sinus through the canine fossa. The incision is made in the gingivobuccal sulcus, specifically in the upper gingivolabial fold above the premolar or canine tooth. This approach allows direct entry into the anterior wall of the maxillary sinus, facilitating drainage and surgical access. It avoids external scarring since the incision is inside the mouth. Incorrect Options: Option A (Palpebral Sulcus) The palpebral sulcus is located in the eyelid and is not involved in the Caldwell-Luc procedure. This approach is not used to access the maxillary sinus. Option B (Inferior Orbital Sulcus) The inferior orbital sulcus is a groove in the floor of the orbit carrying the infraorbital nerve and vessels. Surgical access via this area risks injury to the infraorbital nerve, leading to numbness of the cheek, upper lip, and teeth. Option C (Chiasmatic Sulcus) The chiasmatic sulcus is located in the sphenoid bone, near the optic chiasm, and has no relation to the Caldwell-Luc procedure.
